Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2011 05:18PM Elizabeth27 wrote: Maria, Thanks so much for starting this thread. I am from the Jan thread too. I had my BMX with TEs on 1/5. My PS is very strict, didn't want me walking outside in case I slipped o the ice etc. BUT he did give me permission to go on the stationary bike after two weeks, and the elliptical after 4 weeks. I usually do yoga but I have heard a lot of stories of women ripping some internal stitching and I think it is SO important not to mess things up. I am going to the gym almost everyday and doing either 45 min on the bike or 30 min on the elliptical. I do my stretching exercises at home every day although I have been less good about those. My ROM seems pretty good. I am going on vacation next week, and look forward to swimming in warm water altho the PS said not to do rigorous crawl, just gentle paddling around. We'll see! Maria, I did 4 rounds of TC. It is not a walk in the park, but it is doable and will be over before you know it. Good for you for doing the cold caps. I have a friend who did and she was very pleased. I was too lazy and my treatment center was not encouraging. I am 3 months out form chemo now and still wearing a wig. I am getting hair but it is slow. I would feel over the chemo if it weren't for the hair (and nails are still a bit funky). Feel free to PM me if you have any specific questions.
Posts.Title: Jan 2011 gals - post op exercise check in! mdg redskyatnight

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2010 08:57PM Elizabeth27 wrote: Hi Lizzy et al., First let me say again, I LOVE this group! You are a remarkable group of women, caring, smart and brave. Now that I have buttered you up, may I ask ot become an official member? I have posted occasionally and followed every post. I'll leave it up to your fearless leader. It is interesting what you say about the newbies being afraid and then most people shifting to wanting to get it over with ASAP. I think that I am some where in between. my chemo teaching nurse had led me to believe that my side effects wouldn't be too bad and then I was really slammed the first time. I had every SE in the book and more. I went back to work after a week worrying that I should have been wearing Depends just in case! I now have TC #2 on Wed and am both extremely apprehensive but also eager to be half way through. Sound familiar to anyone? I think that I have been weird about hair too. My onc had said that was the most traumatic part. From my perspective it was creepy but not nearly as bad as the SEs. I got the last remnants buzzed off on Friday and it was a relief as it was coming out so fast. The weird part is that I have yet to look in the mirror. I just go from one head covering to another. Btw- I hate the wig. it itches. Guess I will use it for work and go to scarves for home. I had a weird "discovery" too. My tumor was picked up on regular mammogram but was 2.7cm. BS said that it had been there for years, but my old films look "fine". Reading all of your stories, it really strikes me how many stealth tumors there are out there. Makes me want to get on my soap box about the importance of regular mammograms. If they had switched to every other year as the study recommended, many of us would be in much deeper but also the need for even more refined imaging techniques. These tumors are tricky. So, best to all of you for a SE free day. Hope that you will take me into your group. With affection and respect. Elizabeth
Posts.Title: August 2010...anyone starting chemo besides me?! 1WonderWoman 1WonderWoman

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2010 11:47AM Elizabeth27 wrote: Hi All, Iowa, definitely call your onc right away if you are all swollen. My onc said something helpful this week, which is that we all deserve cadillac care right now, and not to use the same standards in deciding whether to call the doctor that we would use when we are "regular" patients. Cancer patients are more vulnerable, and don't need to worry about calling the doctor. Just do it, if you are worried. Lizzy, shouldn't your onc give you some sleep meds? You need your rest. I am getting extra roids because of my weird allergy issues so they gave me some Ambien and it really helps. A word of admiration to the mothers of young children. I love your parenting stories and how well you are handling all those hard conversations and embarassing moments with your kids. I have no idea how you are handling all the SEs and fatigue and still taking care of a young family. My kids are 17 and 21. I don't know how I would have managed if they were younger. of course keeping after my son to do his college applications is a hassle, but I can do it form the couch. For those who were looking for easy family friendly recipes. Martha's Stewart's Everyday Food magazine has a website. If you google Everyday food it comes up, and they have reasonable easy, healthy recipes. My treat for this week. They have decided I am allergic to taxotere, which is then making me allergic to other things(like wig hair). One choice is to start over on AC (no thanks!) or do a slow densitization infusion over six hours, with one on one nursing, I guess to make sure I keep breathing. I think they start out with very dilute solution, give a little, wait a while, then give a slightly more concentrated amount etc. of course this also involves LOTS of steroids.  Apparently they have been doing this for a while at Dana Farber with success. So I go in at 7AM on Friday for basically the whole day.  I get the sense that people are getting more worn down and weary. As my onc always signs off "Hang in There" we are getting closer. I send congrats to those who are done, and encouragement to all who are getting closer every day. Elizabeth
Posts.Title: August 2010...anyone starting chemo besides me?! 1WonderWoman 1WonderWoman

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2010 10:11PM Elizabeth27 wrote: Lizzy, They decided that I was allergic to taxotere because at the beginning of my second treatment (which is a 2nd exposure, as with a food allergy the 2nd exposure is when you react) my throat got very tight, I had trouble breathing and got very flushed. They were able to continue the infusion after giving me lots of IV steroids and benedryl. I have been breaking out in hives intermitently since the infusion so the allergist thinks the taxotere sent my immune system into overdrive and that another infusion would be "dangerous" without the desensitization. It was either that or start over again with other agents. No thanks. I think that many people here talk about being more easily winded. I think an actual allergy would present more dramatically, but it is worth asking the onc about as the allergist says that 10% of people have reactions to taxotere. Seems pretty high. Wherria, did you make it to the marathon. It was a beautiful day. Hope that you did.
Posts.Title: August 2010...anyone starting chemo besides me?! 1WonderWoman 1WonderWoman

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2010 03:22PM Elizabeth27 wrote: wherria, I just did some research on the "just T&C" thread, and found an interesting post. Of course I pass this along knowing that it isn't "science" but someone said that her onc had said that the data about 4 vs 6 treatments is still out. Her onc had recommended 6 cycles because she had a high oncotype score and grade but said that the studies are still underway. To me that sounds like there is a regular regimen of 4, but that some docs use 6 based on their clinical judgement that it might be helpful. Elizabeth
Posts.Title: August 2010...anyone starting chemo besides me?! 1WonderWoman 1WonderWoman

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2010 11:09AM Elizabeth27 wrote: Good Morning, I have two questions that I wonder if anyone can help me with...  1. My onc offered me the option of not having the Neulasta shot after my last TC treatment, as I don't have to have counts up so fast if not having another treatment. Has anyone else cnosidered this or had their TC without Neulasta? Is it okay? 2. Has anyone had the CYP test for Tomoxifen sensitivity? I heard there is a test to see if you are likely to be a good responder to Tomoxifen, but my onc has not suggested it. I am thinking of asking for it. Has anyone else gotten it? heard about it?  Any thoughts would be much appreciated!
Posts.Title: August 2010...anyone starting chemo besides me?! 1WonderWoman 1WonderWoman

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2011 12:01PM Elizabeth27 wrote: Hello all, I haven't posted in months and months, but check in sometimes to see how everyone is doing. It is amazing that we are all getting to the one year mark. It is hard  to know how to acknowledge the "anniversary". What a year!  Lizzie, I read about your scan and blood work. Scary. That out of control feeling is SO hard, AND so is the waiting. I send you all sorts of good karma from Boston..hoping for good news on the scan. There are lots of false positives on those things. You are amazingly fiesty, and deal so well with all that comes your way. I am sure that you will continue to. You are as always, our fearless leader.   All the Best to everyone, Elizabeth
Posts.Title: August 2010...anyone starting chemo besides me?! 1WonderWoman 1WonderWoman

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2010 11:35AM Elizabeth27 wrote: I'm so glad that someone brought up headaches. My chemo nurse mentioned the anti nausea drugs as a possible cause too, but I don't think that is it. I got horrendous headaches from day 4-8 (too late for it to be the anti nausea drugs) and the wig just makes them worse. I am wondering how many of you head aches sufferers are on Taxotere? That is my current bet as the culprit.I think it also causes the congestion and the sniffles as it can cause an allergic type reaction.  Not to scare people but I had chest tightening with my 2nd TC infusion. They gave me a large IV infusion of steroids and started again, with success. I guess you never know what wonderful SEs can make an appearance! Congratulations to those who are done. Wishing everyone else a SE free weekend! Elizabeth
Posts.Title: August 2010...anyone starting chemo besides me?! 1WonderWoman 1WonderWoman

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2010 01:07PM Elizabeth27 wrote: Hi All,  Thanks for your support and understanding about the taxotere allergy saga. I ended up having a ten hour infusion in an allergy densitization unit on Friday and it went well. Might have been overkill, probably would have been fine with extra benedryl and roids, but it is what the allergist recommended, and it worked! My message is....don't fear any possible allergic response, because even though mine was dramatic, ultimately it was managable. Ideas about tother things....Lizzie you mentioned a need for good scentless moisturizers. I have been using Kheil's for my face (expensive, but a little goes a long way) and Cetaphil, which is awesome, effective and cheap at CVS. Cetaphil was recommended by the LGFB woman, nad my daughter who has major dry skin issues. I wish everyone a SE free, lovely weekend! Elizabeth
Posts.Title: August 2010...anyone starting chemo besides me?! 1WonderWoman 1WonderWoman

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2011 12:10PM Elizabeth27 wrote: Hi All, Had my BMX with TEs on Wed, home Friday, feeling pretty good all things considered. Yes, Lizzy, chemo was worse! It seems as though most of us are moving onto the hormonal treatment phase of things. I have been reading that for post menopausal women AIs are slightly more effective than Tomoxifen. My onc is recommending 2-3 years of Tomoxifen followed by 2-3 years of an AI. She believes it is better to build up the bones before taking something that has weakens the bones. I am curious what is being recommended to the rest of you?

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2010 08:01AM Elizabeth27 wrote: Hi ladies, I need some help. Just today my hair started coming out. Every time I run my fingers through I get quite a bit. I have a wig and plan on getting it buzzed. How quickly does it come out? Can I wait to next week? I have plans to go away this weekend and would rather wait until after, but don't want to show up bald at work on Monday. Any advice will be much appreciated! Elizabeth
Posts.Title: August 2010...anyone starting chemo besides me?! 1WonderWoman 1WonderWoman

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2010 11:50AM Elizabeth27 wrote: Lizzy, that is good news. All this stuff is so scary, and the places our minds take us....As for your onc, glad you saw him but you need to advocate to see him more regularly, even if he is an academic etc. My onc is also an academic and clinical head of the bc center at Dana Farber, but she sees her patients before every other treatment alternating with her nurse practicioner. That works pretty well. She is also accessible by email, which is great. OK, people I need your help with my problem of the week. I had an allergic reaction during my TC infusion #2, then this week on day 12 I developed hives all over my head, neck, face and hands. My eyelids swelled up so much that I burst capillaries and look as though I have shiners. They started me back on steroids to treat the hives. I am also congested and have bronchospasm, all allergic. I have never had allergies before this treatment. Seems I might have an allergic reaction to the already not beloved wig, or maybe to the "hat hair" I just got this weekend (a baseball cap with a fringe of synthetic hair attached). Have any of you heard of anything like this? It seems to me that I once read someone's posting about developing asthma on taxotere, or did I make that up. I am hoping to see an allergist before next weeks' treatment! Yikes!
Posts.Title: August 2010...anyone starting chemo besides me?! 1WonderWoman 1WonderWoman

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2010 04:56AM Elizabeth27 wrote: Hi All,  I am feeling a need to apologize for the content of some of my posts. I think I gave insufficient thought to how potentially anxiety provoking it would be to others to hear about my allergic responses to Taxotere. I am thinking particularly of you, Calamtykel. I think that I posted hoping to hear how others who might have had this experience had handled it, but I gave insufficient thought to how it would feel to those about to start on one of the taxols. I remember that there was someone who did have trouble who posted early on, so when I had my response it actually was helpful to me to have heard about it (my onc team had not mentioned such a possibility) but I now realize that I probably caused more anxiety. That was certainly not my intent, and to those for whom that was true, I am very sorry. Most reactions, if they occur at all are mild, and easily handled by the onc team.  All the Best, Elizabeth
Posts.Title: August 2010...anyone starting chemo besides me?! 1WonderWoman 1WonderWoman

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2010 03:58AM Elizabeth27 wrote: Good luck Cal, Sohard and Lizzie, A rant as well....so, so sick of this. I am day 9 after treatment #3 and still don't feel "normal". Went to a Pilates class today, granted by accident it was a more advanced one than I usually attend, but I was so weak! I couldn't do half of what I usually do, and ended up in tears. THEN I get to go home and get ready for work, and I am completely wiped out. I think that most of us are about 3/4 of the way through. Perhaps this is the worst point. The light is at the end of the tunnel, but that doesn't feel so great, when each day is hard. Question,,,are we allowed to talk about sex here? or is it too x rated? My question...does anyone have any interest at all? Not me. Also pretty itchy and dry. Ugh.  Hang in there all.

Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2011 06:47PM Elizabeth27 wrote: My biopsy took about 45 minutes, and a couple of days to get the results. I would say bring someone. I was SO glad that I did. My biopsy was painful as I wasn't given enough lidocaine, so make sure they give you plenty. It was good to have my husband there. Most biopsies are negative, but in my case it was clear that the radiologist was pretty sure it was cancer. I was upset afterwards and I wouldn't have wanted to be by myself. It is better to have company and not need it, than to not have anyone there and wish that you did. Fortunately the odds are with you that it will be benign. Hope all goes well!
Posts.Title: core biopsy mudd SarahsMom

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2010 08:24PM Elizabeth27 wrote: Hi All, I have been lurking, following all of you closely, but haven't posted for a while. Congrats to Cal, Rachel and Lisa. It was helpful hearing your reactions to being done with chemo. I finished two weeks ago today, and finally am feeling happy and THANKFUL (to all my friends and family who have been so good to me and to all of you for support, and sharing your journeys), but my first reaction was definitely anticlimactic. It was more relief and some disbelief...can this chapter really be over?  I also turned my thoughts immediately to the next chapter, which I imagine many of the rest of you will do too, as this isn't the last step of treatment for many of us. I am headed towards a BMX with TEs in early Jan. I know some of you have been through this. Any advice would be MUCH appreciated. I  have started following some of the mastectomy threads. It all sound scary. The whole thing makes me feel sad, but it is about time (I had a lumpectomy and re-excision over the summer, all invasive cancer was removed, but there were patches of DCIS) I wish you all a Happy Holiday, and few SEs so that you can enjoy it!

I am a month out from chemo and still have no hair. I am wondering what those of you in my situation did during surgery. The wig seems cumbersome, and as though it will get moved around. A scarf would be hard to tie afterwards. I have a little cap that I wear when I am sleeping, which is comfortable but not too attractive. If anyone has had experience with this, I would really appreciate hearing about it. Many thanks, Susan
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2010 10:01PM Elizabeth27 wrote: Kelly and Teri,  I friend of mine who had a BMX in June said to work on your core and quads. Getting up and down, especially out of bed is challenging. I am not looking forward to the limitations on movement. I have had 8 weeks between chemo and surgery and have been trying to be as active as possible to regain some strength before being knocked over again. I have gone to Pilates and yoga and am working with a trainer who has had at least some experience with mastectomy patients. My PS says that he worries more about people doing too much too soon after surgery. I guess that we will have to be patient and let people take care of us! Thanks for the welcomes  Elizabeth
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2011 10:54PM Elizabeth27 wrote: Hi All,  Thanks for all the good wishes.  It has been a long hard day, spent time getting organized, packing for the hospital, getting a million pillows ready for when I come home. The only time I relaxed was at my hot yoga class (it is hard to stay anxious there!). Jackie and MeJoy, I'll be thinking of you and send you all good wishes. I'll report back from the other side of surgery! Elizabeth
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2011 05:16PM Elizabeth27 wrote: Hi All, I had my BMX with TEs on Wed.and came home yesterday. I had no trouble with the anesthesia, but feel as though a truck is parked on my chest. The expanders make my chest feel very tight, and there is a pinching where the drains go through the skin, but it is bearable, not horrible pain.I get charlie horse like spasms across my chest when I stand up. I am taking the pain meds every four hours as directed and not trying to brave out the pain.  For those of you yet to go, I recommend getting the c-shaped travel pillow for sleeping. It makes a huge difference. Also if I had it to do over again I would start Colace before surgery. The pain meds are very constipating. I bought a camisole and belt to hold drains but my surgeon put me in a tight surgical compression bra to keep the swelling down, so I haven't used the other things that I bought.  EVERYONE said that the anticipation is worse than the actual event and I really think that is true. Even without my breasts, I still feel like me (haven't dared look yet and won't for a while) and I feel relieved that the dangerous cells are gone. It IS a big surgery, physically and emotionally, but scared as you may be, you CAN do it. One last thing...move your clothes to lower shelves as well as things in your bathroom and some glasses, bowls etc in the kitchen. Soon we will all be on the road to healing and leaving this chapter behind us. My thoughts are with all of you who go next. Please PM me if you have any specific questions. Very gentle hugs, Elizabeth
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

I can see why everyone says this is a slow process, but each day is better and it hasn't even been a week yet. Hang in there ladies! Elizabeth
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2010 12:59PM Elizabeth27 wrote: Hi All,  I am here to join the club that no one wants to join! I do appreciate having your good company, however. One woman in the Dec. thread wrote how we are all like passengers on a plane, wearing parachutes and jumping one by one as our date arrives. I thought it was an apt metaphor.   I was diagnosed on July with IDC, had a lumpectomy and SNB on 7/21, didn't have clear margins so had a re-excision on 8/2. That one was clear for invasive CA, but there were patches of DCIS. My docs decided to delay my next surgery until after chemo. I had TC X 4, finished in Nov. and am scheduled for a BMX with TEs on Jan 6.  My PS is very conservative and won't start fills until 3 weeks after drains are removed. I am filled with dread about the surgery, disturbed about the bodily changes etc.,  but also have been on this path for many months and would like to move on. Everything has felt quite dragged out. I wish all of you the best holidays possible given our circumstances. Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2010 12:07PM Elizabeth27 wrote: Welcome Jackie, It looks as though we are set for surgery the same day. Have you had a previous surgery? I had a lumpectomy in July and re-excision for lack of clear margins in August. Are you as nervous as I am? I vacillate between wanting to get it over with and pure dread! Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2011 08:38PM Elizabeth27 wrote: Hi All, A word of caution about exercising too soon. I am a week out tomorrow from BMX with TEs, and have been taking walks outside for the past 3 days, which has been nice. My PS warned against doing too much with my arms as the TEs can get displaced. I know a couple of women who opened their incisions or disruption their recon by working out too soon after surgery. Remember the chest wall will be numb from the nerves that are cut, so be very careful. I too, hope to be back at the gym and yoga ASAP, but it probably helps to work with a trainer who has familiarity with BC patients or a physical therapist. Good luck to those of you going tomorrow. It is NOT as bad as you fear! Elizabeth
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 08:37PM Elizabeth27 wrote: Hi Ladies, For whatever it is worth, I found the wedge very helpful in keeping me on my back, but also put a pillow under my knees which also helped. got my last drain out yesterday (10days out) and thought I could immediately sleep on my side, but the TEs make it sore. I am trying to rearrange the pillow to lean slightly sideways. Progress is slow, but there is progress. What are your doctors telling you about driving? Mine says that I can do a little local driving now that the drains are out. I have been walking every day, but he says to stop because of the risk of slipping on the ice. He is SO conservative. Have you all been looking at your incisions? I took my first shower today, and got a good look. Quite a shock! I guess this is real! Good luck to all of you who go next week. Just remember, it is uncomfortable but not painful. May all your surgeries go well. Elizabeth
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 09:16PM Elizabeth27 wrote: Lisa, My PS said that it was okay for me to drive after all the drains were out (at least locally), which for me was 10 days post op.  He is less happy with my walking, which I had been doing every day because of all the ice we have in Massachusetts. One tip that I got from a Dec. woman who PMed me. Bed, Bath & Beyond has small "travel pillows". I bought three of them and have them wedged in various places (e.g. behind my back) to keep me in a relatively comfortable position while I am sleeping.  I am three weeks out today, and went to the gym once so far to ride on the stationary bike. I couldn't get off the couch for the rest of the day, but it is start! A question for those of you who are a few weeks out......I am SO tired still. I can do a couple of things during the day e.g. go out to lunch, stop at the market etc. but I am totally wiped out afterwards. How are the rest of you doing with fatigue? I did chemo first, so maybe it that contributes to the exhaustion. I have to go back to work soon, and am worried. To all of you having surgery this week.....it isn't nearly as bad as you are anticipating. You will be on the healing side soon!
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2010 08:36AM Elizabeth27 wrote: cmblastic, I remember the exhaustion at the end of chemo all to well. I see that you live in Florida. How about just walking everyday? i did that at the beginning post chemo and tried to go a little further each day. Someone who has worked with BC patients recommended stretching out the pectoral muscles in doorways with arms on the frames to open up the chest wall area. Stamina comes back slowly, but it comes...  Good luck, Susan
